  CHAPTER I. 
STATISTICAL SURVEY OF EDUCATION FOR THE YEARS 
1915 AND 1916. 
I, SURVEY FOR THE YEAR 1915. 
The total enrollment in all schools and colleges in 1915 was 
23,113,931. This number includes 1,155,095 in miscellaneous 
schools, a number which is Jargely estimated and is omitted from 
the succeeding tables. The comparative summaries are based upon 
the total 21,958,836 as given in the first part of Table 1. This 
number is made up from reasonably full reports from individual 
institutions, the only partly estimated number included being that 
of the enrollment in private elementary schools.

-P-A-G-E-12
EDUCATION REPORT, 1917. 
  The average length of the school term for 1915 was 159.4 days. In 
one State the schools were open 194.5 days and in another only 110 
days. The term exceeded 180 days in five States; in 19 States it fell 
below 160 days, 11 of these States having a term of less than 140 days. 
The average number of days’ attendance for every child 5 to 18 years 
of age (i. e., 5 to 17, inclusive) was 90.4 days, varying from 51.4 in 
the State having the lowest average to 123.5 in the two States having 
the highest. 
TaBLE 3.—Average number of years’ (of 200 days) attendance at public schools for each 
individual, as indicated by the school statistics for the years named. 
  
Divisions. 1870 | 1875 | 1880 | 1885 | 1890 | 1895 | 1900 | 1905 | 1910 | 1915 
  
-| 2.91 | 8.32 | 3.45 | 3.69 | 3.85 | 4.35 | 4.67 | 4.81 | 5.40 | 5.88 
4,74 | 4.84 | 5.02 | 4.99 | 5.51 | 5.91 | 6.17 | 6.38} 6.76 
3.91 | 4.19 | 4.37 | 4.67 | 5.27 | 5.57 | 5.58 | 6.28 | 6.83 The United States. 
    
  1.70 | 1.90 | 2.19 | 2.42 | 2.73 | 2.95 | 3.26 | 3.93 | 4.43 
. 1.53 | 1.57 | 2.04 | 2.20 | 2.69 | 2.91 | 2.85 | 3.77! 4.23 
Western Division. . . 8.48 | 3.57 | 3.79 | 3.98 | 5.04 | 4.99 | 5.85 | 6.29 
  
At the rate of 90.4 days per year, in 13 years (the period of school 
life, 5 to 18) a child entering school at 5 years of age would receive 
1,175 days schooling, or 5.88 years of 200 days. In this estimate it is 
necessary to assume that the percentage of enrollment, average 
attendance, and length of school term computed for 1915 may con- 
tinue for 13 years. Table 3 compares this estimate with similar esti- 
mates for former years. 
Table 4 shows that, by combining the estimate for private schools 
with the above for public schools, the number of days schooling for 
each individual is increased to 1,264 days, or 6.32 years of 200 days 
each. 
Tasie 4.—Average number of years’ (of 200 days) schooling at any school received by 
each individual, as indicated by the statistics for the years named. 
  
In public schools | In public and pri- 
only. vate schools. 
Years. 
Days. | Years. | Days. | Years. 
  
  582 2.91 672 3.36 690 3.45 792 3.96 770 3.85 892 4. 46 934 467] 1,046 5.23 1,079 5.40] 1,173 5.87 1,175 5.88] 1,264 6.32 
  
The Census Office in 1910 reported the approximate number of 
children in certain age groups who were attending school. By 
applying the percentage of the total found in each group to the total 
enrollment reported to the Bureau of Education in 1915, a similar
-P-A-G-E-13
  SURVEY OF EDUCATION FOR THE YEAR 1915. iu. 
age distribution may be obtained. The number not in school is 
obtained by subtraction from the estimated population by age 
groups which is based upon the Census figures of 1910. 
These estimates are shown in Table 5.

1 Includes enrollment 21 years of age and over. 
In 1915 the total enrollment of 21,958,836, as previously shown in 
Table 2, was distributed as follows: 19,990,316 in elementary schools, 
1,564,972 in high schools, academies, and secondary schools, and 
403,548 in higher institutions. An estimate of the number in each 
grade may be obtained by applying the approximate percentages for 
public elementary schools and the actual percentages for secondary 
schools, with the result shown in Table 6. 
TaBE 6.—Distribution of school enrollment for 1915 according to estimated percentages.

The percentage of grade distribution has probably preserved prac- 
tically the same ratio for the past eight years. The application of 
the above approximate percentages to the enrollment of various 
years shows that in 1907 there were enrolled in the first grade
-P-A-G-E-14
  8 EDUCATION REPORT, 1917. 
4,066,091 pupils, 2,435,529 were in the fourth grade in 1910, the 
eighth grade in 1914 had 1,244,098, while 629,432 reached the first 
year of the high school in 1915. This progress of grade enrollment 
is shown in Table 7. 
Tasie 7.—Progress of elementary-grade enrollment for eight years.

It is generally estimated that about one-half of the first-grade 
enrollment is made up of beginners, the other half being comprised 
of repeaters or retarded pupils. Assuming that 2,000,000 of the 
first-grade enrollment in 1907 were repeaters, the beginners that year 
numbered about 2,066,091, of whom 629,432, or about 30 per cent, 
reached the first year of the high school in 1914-15. 
The enrollment of first-year high-school students for four suc- 
cessive years and the number of graduates for four years later are 
shown in Table 8. From this table it will be seen that about 39 
per cent, or 245,478, of the 629,432 students entering the high school 
in 1914 may be expected to graduate in 1918. 
TABLE 8.—Elimination of high-school students. 
  
  First-year students. | Fourth-year graduates. 
: | Sick e Flimi- Year of Percent | nated. Years. Number.| gradua- | Number. ee e 
oo | students.   
393, 260 | 1911-12 
430,280 | 1912-13 
463,187 | 1913-14 
506,860 | 1914-15 155,656 | 30.58 | 237, 604 167,117 | 38.84] 263, 163 180, 909 | 39.06 | 282) 278 
     1911-12. - 198, 341 39.13 308, 519 
  
From the above tables it may be estimated that about 117 in every 
1,000 pupils entering the first grade in 1906-7 will graduate from the 
high school in 1918. 
THE COST OF EDUCATION. 
The cost of education in the United States in 1915 as shown in 
Table 9 was $855,039,511. The expenditures of State school systems 
and of all public institutions and of institutions of higher education 
 
-P-A-G-E-15

are reported by State superintendents or by individual institutions 
and are reasonably accurate. For the remaining groups estimates 
were necessary.

From 1871 to 1915 the gifts and bequests to education have aggre- 
gated $610,441,328. The amount received by schools and colleges 
for each separate year is shown in Table 11.

were employed in the United States 731,494 teachers, 173,139 men 
and 558,355 women. The number of teachers in private elementary 
and miscellaneous schools is partly estimated. :

COMMON SCHOOLS OF THE SOUTH. 
In 18 Southern States the schools for Negro children are separate 
from the white schools. Separate accounts of the cost of mainten- 
ance of white and Negro schools are not kept in most of these States. 
Table 18 shows the population, enrollment, average attendance, num- 
ber of teachers, etc. in white and Negro schools of the Southern

States in 1915. The aggregate expenditure for schools of both races 
in these States was $118,002,755, as shown in Table 19.

explanation of these tables consult the survey for 1915, which may 
be found in the preceding pages.

-P-A-G-E-34
| 28 EDUCATION REPORT, 1917. 
KINDERGARTEN STATISTICS FOR 1916. 
Tables 12 and 13 are summaries of figures pertaining to kinder- 
gartens in the United States for the school year 1915-16, compiled 
by the Kindergarten Division of the Bureau of Education. An 
encouraging increase is noted in the number of public-school kinder- 
gartens established throughout the country during the year, while 
the number of kindergartens other than public shows a decrease, 
owing to the fact that many of the latter have been taken over by 
public-school boards. 
The total number of kindergartens in both public and other than 
public schools in 1916 was 10,015 and the enrollment 509,112, while 
the attendance numbered 295,941. The gains in kindergartens, 
enrollment, and attendance over the preceding year amounted to 
529, 22,312, and 5,742, respectively. 
_ Cities reporting that they had public-school kindergartens last 
year numbered 1,228, which is 123 more than reported such classes 
in 1915. There were, in all, 8,463 public kindergartens, an increase 
of 589 for the year, while the number of children enrolled was 434,022, 
an increase of 24,939. The average attendance was 247,944, showing 
8,601 more than for the preceding year. 
The number of kindergartens other than public in 1916 was 1,552 
and the enrollment 75,090, a decrease of 60 kindergartens and of 
2,627 children since 1915. 
A study of the geographical distribution of kindergartens shows 
that the most noticeable gains have been made in the North Central 
and Western States. In the North Central Division 3,751 public- 
school kindergartens were reported in 1916, which is 414 more than 
existed in 1915. The Western Division shows 655 kindergartens, as 
compared with 543 for the previous year. 
The States in which the increase in enrollment has been most 
marked are: Massachusetts and New York in the North Atlantic 
Division; Ohio, Illinois, Michigan, Iowa, South Dakota, and Nebraska 
in the North Central; South Carolina in the South Atlantic; and | 
Montana and California in the Western Division. California stands 
out especially for establishing 94 additional kindergartens in 26 cities 
and towns, with an increased enrollment of 3,829 children. Montana 
has also taken a stride forward by changing its record of last year of 
6 kindergartens in one city, with an enrollment of 115 children, to 31 
kindergartens in six cities with 964 children enrolled. 
Two hundred and sixty kindergartens have been established in 140 
cities and towns which never had them before. California takes the 
lead in this particular also, with 38 kindergartens in 21 different 
places. Iowa follows, with 20 kindergartens in 13 places, while the  
-P-A-G-E-35
SURVEY OF EDUCATION FOR THE YEAR 1916, 29 
following States. rank close in line: Michigan, Minnesota, Illinois, 
Wisconsin, and New York. 
The status of the movement in many parts of the country shows 
such encouraging, as well as interesting, progress that a few typical 
examples may well be cited. Chicago, with a population of 2,000,000 
and 376 kindergartens already, reports that its school officials have 
been given unlimited authority by their board of education to pro- 
vide all their elementary schools with such classes wherever the 
attendance justifies taking such a step. Buffalo, N. Y., with a 
population of 423,000 and 121 kindergartens at the present time, is 
attempting to do the same thing and has recently opened 9 new 
classes. This takes care of all the schools except three, and these, 
it is planned, are to have kindergarten classes added next year. 
Kansas City, Mo., with a population of 248,000, conducts 77 kinder- 
gartens and reports that it can be placed in the list of school districts 
maintaining such classes for all pupils between 5 and 6 years of age, 
inasmuch as it has adopted the policy of opening a class in every 
elementary school in which there is a sufficient number of children 
to justify this action. Pasadena, Cal., with a population of 30,000, 
conducts 15 kindergartens. It has had a kindergarten connected 
with each of its elementary schools for many years and is thoroughly 
committed to this department of education, believing it to be the 
most important single phase in all elementary work. Plainfield, N.J., 
with a population of 20,000, has had a kindergarten in all its primary 
buildings for many years and never considers the erection of a new 
building without planning for a kindergarten room. It has 11 kin- 
dergartens at the present time. Long Beach, Cal., having a popu- 
lation of 17,000, reports that its 14 kindergartens, one in each of its 
elementary schools, takes care of all the children in the city between 
the ages of 4 and 6 for whom this training is desired. Pomona, Cal., 
with a population of 10,000, has had 6 kindergartens, one in every 
elementary school, for 22 years. The kindergarten has recently been 
made a regular part of the elementary course, and this year it was 
found that 93 per cent of its first-grade children had had kindergarten 
training, or 189 out of 214 enrolled. Titusville, Pa., with a popula- 
tion of 8,000, has a kindergarten in every grammar school. The 
system has been in full operation for at least 15 years, and both the 
community and school administration regard it as a valuable part 
of the public-school work. Many other cities report that they have 
kindergartens in all their elementary schools. 
In several cities the school authorities have shown increased inter- 
est in the kindergarten as a result of privately initiated movements. 
For instance, in Hutchinson, Kans., there is a kindergarten, privately 
conducted, for which the board of education has only been able to
-P-A-G-E-36
  30 EDUCATION REPORT, 1917, 
provide and furnish a room in a public-school building. The super- 
intendent of Hutchinson hopes in due time that the kindergarten will 
be run entirely by the board of education and that it may lead to 
the establishment of kindergartens in all the schools of the city. 
Mendon, Mich., has accomplished in part the result hoped for by 
Hutchinson. A kindergarten conducted for three years in this city 
under the management of the Women’s Club, recently had to be dis- 
continued on account of lack of funds, but the public sentiment 
aroused by this private work was so strong that this year the public- 
school board incorporated the kindergarten in its school system. 
Again, cities are reporting experimental kindergarten work car- 
ried on with a view to proving the value of this kind of training 
before definitely incorporating it in the school curriculum. Youngs- 
town, Ohio, introduced kindergarten methods in this way last Feb- 
ruary, with the result that one kindergarten has now been perma- 
nently established. An experiment made in Houston Heights, Tex., 
proved so satisfactory that the school officials contemplate a kinder- 
garten in each of the grade schools for next year. 
Encouraging reports have also been received from a number of 
cities and towns which give interesting evidence that they will estab- 
lish kindergartens in the near future. Forty-seven places report 
kindergarten work conducted in connection either with the subpri- 
mary or first grade. 
The growth of kindergartens in cities, towns, and industrial villages 
of this country during 1916 has been in keeping with the record of the 
past six or seven years, which has shown more progress in this respect 
than any previous period of equal length. This is especially true of 
kindergartens supported by school funds. This progress had been 
due largely, it is believed, to the efforts being made to spread the 
knowledge of the kindergarten and to arouse the demand for kinder- 
garten classes, which were begun on a national organized basis 
about eight years ago.
-P-A-G-E-37
SURVEY OF EDUCATION FOR THE YEAR 1916, 31

-P-A-G-E-41
  CHAPTER II. 
STATE SCHOOL SYSTEMS, 1915 AND 1916. 
THE YEAR 1914-15. 
The summaries of State schools which are here presented relate 
exclusively to public elementary and high schools, maintained by 
State and local taxation. City and village systems are included. 
Statistics of State school systems for 1916 will be found beginning 
on page 64. 
Such statistics as it was possible to obtain from outlying posses- 
sions of the United States are shown in the 1916 tables. These 
figures are not complete and are not included in the total amounts 
of the divisions and the United States. 
As the school census age is not the same in all States, it is necessary 
for purposes of comparison to assume a uniform school age. The 
Bureau of Education for many years has compared the reports of 
enrollment and attendance with the estimated population 5 to 18 
years of age (i. e., 5 to 17, inclusive). This estimate is made annually 
by applying the percentage of 5 to 17 at the last census to the Census 
Office estimates of the total population. 
Number of children 5 to 18 years of age (5 to 17, inclusive) to every 100 persons of the total 
population. 
  
1870 1880 | 1890 1900 1910 
  
    
    
  
  United States..... 30.04 | 29.61 28. 35, 26.35 
North Atlantic Division 26. 87 25.39 24, 42 23.47 
North Central Division . 30. 63 29.33 28. 24 25.50 
South Atlantic Division 32.24 34.04 31.79 30.34 
South Central Division. 33.13 34. 76 32. 84 31.3 
Western Division.... 25.13 24.33, 25.06 22.13 
  The preceding table shows a relative decrease in the ratio of chil- 
dren to adult population for five decennial years. This decrease is 
partly due to the addition of foreign-born adults to our population, 
but it is caused mainly by the decreasing birth rate. 
The following synopsis shows the estimated school population in 
two groups, 5 to 14 and 14 to 17 years. The total population 5 to 
18 (5 to 17, inclusive) for 1915 was 26,425,100.

It is not possible at this time to make a close estimate of the number 
of children of each age, but the approximate distribution by certain 
age groups, based upon the percentages of the last census, will be 
found most useful in the comparison of school statistics. This esti- 
mate is given in the following table:

Rural population was defined by the Census Office in 1910 as the 
population outside of cities of 2,500 inhabitants. At that time 53.7 
of the total population was found in the rural districts. The per- 
centages ascertained for 1910 may be applied to the 1915 population 
to show the approximate distribution of urban and rural population 
for that year, as given in the following table: 
Estimated population per square mile, and urban and rural population, 1915.

STATE SCHOOL SYSTEMS, 1914—15, 37 
Nearly 54 per cent of the total population is rural, while almost 60 
per cent of the school population is found in rural communities. The 
age grouping corresponding nearest to the 5 to 17 group which can be 
given accurately is the 6 to 20 group given by the Census Office in 1910, 
If the same ratio is applied to the 1915 population, the approximate 
apportionment of like population will be found as shown in the fol- 
lowing table: 
Urban and rural population 6 to 20 years of age, inclusive, estimated for 1915. 
  Population, 6 to 20. Urban, 6 to 20. Rural, 6 to 20.

As only about one-third of the States report elementary enrollment 
by grades, it is impossible to give accurate statistics of grade enroll- ~ 
ment. In the number of States reporting by grades each geographical 
division is represented, making it possible to approximate the enroll- 
ment in each grade for the divisions. This estimate is shown in the 
following table. The second part of the table, showing high-school 
enrollment by years, is not an estimate. It shows the actual enroll- 
ment as reported to the Bureau of Education by high-school principals 
in 1915.

6Minors between 14 and 17 legally employed 
must attend approved schools 4 to 5 hours a week. 
7 Tf legally employed all minors of 13 aud 14, and those of 15 and 16 who have not completed the ele- mentary grades, must attend school 100 days; full 
term when not thus employed. 8 Local option.

may extend compulsory school years to 13 or 14. 107-12 in country districts; 7-16in cities.

214-16 if not able to read and write.

4 Minors between 14 and 16 legally employed must 
attend approved schools at least 8 hours each week. 
5 14-16 if unemployed. 6 Minors between 14and 17 legally employed must attend approved schools 4 to 5 hours a week. 
7 If legally employed all minors of 13 and 14, and those of 15 and 16 who have not completed the ele- 
mentary grades, must attend school 100 days; full 
term when not thus employed. In towns of over 2,000 population loral boards may extend compulsory school years to 13 or 14. 10 7-12 in country districts; 7-16 in cities.

12 8-14 in New Orleans which has separate law. 
13 When term is 140 days or less. 
1480 days in 1917-18; 100 days thereafter.

in 9 counties; 28 counties have no compulsory law.

-P-A-G-E-90

-P-A-G-E-91
         CHAPTER III. 
STATISTICS OF CITY SCHOOL SYSTEMS, 1915-16. 
The cities of 5,000 population and over numbered 1,233 at the last 
census. On account of consolidation there were 1,229 in 1916. 
These cities have 1,241 systems of public schools, 12 of the cities 
having dual systems. 
It has been six years since the Bureau of Education began the col- 
lection of city school statistics on the enlarged schedules now in force. 
This schedule consists of two parts, printed on separate sheets. The 
first part relates to all school statistics other than fiscal, such as the 
teaching force, enrollment, attendance; the second part covers all 
financial items—receipts, expenditures, and value of school property. 
The results of the inquiry for 1916 were much better than in 1915. 
The attendance statistics were not received from 148 school systems, 
while 194 systems failed to report their financial items. For these 
systems which did not report, careful estimates were made, based 
either upon their last report to this office or upon the report of cities 
similar in population and location. These estimates are included in 
the summary, Tables 1 to 12. 
The cities are arranged in four groups. All cities having 100,000 
population and over in 1910 are in the first group, and all below 
100,000, but having 25,000 or over, are in the second group. 
The third group includes all cities of 10,000 population and over, 
but below the second group; while the fourth group includes the 
remaining cities down to 5,000 population. 
The statistics of the separate groups are summarized in Tables 3, 7, 
and 10, while the statistics of the four groups are combined in Tables 
4, 8, and 11. The 1,241 systems had a combined enrollment of 
7,173,112 pupils, and an average attendance of 5,762,197. There 
were 194,449 teachers and 13,269 supervising officers employed. 
The running expense of the systems amounted to $256,941,963, while 
new buildings, sites, equipment, etc., added $58,736,422, making 
with other payments the aggregate expenditure of $357,966.051. 
The salaries of teachers, principals, and supervisors included in the 
above amounted to $187,687,474. 
About 42 per cent of the population of the United States is to be 
found in the cities of 5,000 population and over. These cities have 
about 35 per cent of the school enrollment of the State school sys- 
tems and 38 per cent of the average daily attendance. Of the public- 
school teachers, 33 per cent are in the cities, and they receive about 
51 per cent of the salaries paid to teachers. The running expenses of 
the city systems amount to about 48 per cent of such expenses for the 
85
-P-A-G-E-92
   
   
   
           
    
     
    
     
        
     
     
    
      
      
          
    
     
   
     
    
     
    
   
     
      86 EDUCATION REPORT, 1917. 
United States, and their outlays for buildings, sites, equipment, etc., 
reach 57 per cent. 
The total expenditure for public schools in the cities amounts to 49 
per cent of the aggregate expenditure of the States. 
In Tables 1, 7, and 16, the term ‘Other payments” includes 
redemption, of bonds, redemption of short-term loans, payments of 
warrants and orders of preceding year, payments to sinking funds, 
payments of interest, and miscellaneous payments, including pay- 
ments to trust funds, textbooks to be sold to pupils, etc.

population and over, 1915-16.

  Taste 12.—Summary of teachers and pupils in public evening schools, 1915-16.

CHAPTER TV. 
UNIVERSITIES, COLLEGES, AND TECHNOLOGICAL 
SCHOOLS, 1915-16. 
The tabulated reports of universities, colleges, and technological 
schools for 1915-16 are based upon returns from 574 institutions, as 
compared with 563 institutions for 1914-15. States and municipali- 
ties control 97 of these institutions, and private corporations control 
477. A few colleges have each year failed to report, and when this 
occurs for two years in succession their names are dropped from the 
tabulated list. Additions to the tabulated list include those institu- 
tions from which reports are received after the lapse of two years 
and those which give evidence of reaching satisfactory standards of 
work. The names of the institutions thus added or dropped will be 
found in the following list: 
  CHANGES IN TABULATED LIST OF COLLEGES. 
Colleges (23) tabulated in 1916. but not in 1915.—Athens College, Alabama; Connecti- 
cut-College for Women; American University, District of Columbia; Columbia College, 
Florida; Aurora College, Lincoln College, and Bradley Polytechnic Institute, Illinois; 
Valparaiso University, Indiana; Louisiana College; College of St. Catherine, Minne- 
sota; Christian College and Cottey College, Missouri; Cotner University, Nebraska; 
New York State College of Forestry; Lenoir College, North Carolina; Ohio Northern 
University and Denison University, Ohio; Oklahoma College for Women; St. Joseph’s 
College, Pennsylvania; Columbia College, South Carolina; Richmond College and 
Elizabeth College, Virginia; Spokane College, Washington. 
Colleges (12) not tabulated in 1916 but tabulated in 1915.—Andrew College, Georgia; 
Albert Lea College,' Minnesota; Missouri Wesleyan College; Bellevue College, Ne- 
braska; Keuka College,! New York; Flora MacDonald College, North Carolina; Ash- 
Jand College, Ohio; Claflin University, South Carolina; Redfield College,? South 
Dakota; Southern Presbyterian University and Burritt College, Tennessee; Texas 
Christian University. 
  There were 259,511 students in the collegiate and resident graduate 
departments of universities, colleges, and technological schools. 
The number of such students for each year since 1889-90 is shown 
in the following table: 
1 Closed. 2 Transferred to list of secondary schools. 
99075°—xp 1917—vor 2——19 289

DEGREES CONFERRED. 
  Tables 7, 8, 9, and 10 show the number and kinds of degrees con- 
ferred in 1916 by the 574 institutions. There were 31,826 bacca- 
laureate, 4,524 graduate, and 825 honorary degrees conferred. The 
degree of doctor of philosophy was conferred on examination by 42 
institutions on 520 men and 81 women, as follows: 
Institutions conferring the Ph. D. degree on examination in 1916.

-P-A-G-E-297
  UNIVERSITIES, COLLEGES, AND TECHNOLOGICAL SCHOOLS. 291 
BENEFACTIONS. 
The aggregate of <cluding grants by the 
United States, different States, and municipalities—reported for the 
year 1915-16 was $30,196,006. Of this amount, $6,779,643 was for 
increase of plant, $3,640,000 for current expenses, and $19,776,363 
for endowment. Thirty-five universities, colleges, and technological 
schools reported gifts above $100,000 received during 1915-16, 
amounting to $24,563,831.

-P-A-G-E-377
     CHAPTER V. 
AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGES, 1915-16. 
[The institutions commonly known as “agricultural and mechanical colleges” or “land-grant colleges” 
are brought together in this chapter and made the subject of special treatment. In addition to being con- 
sidered here, the institutions are included in the general tables of the different s of schools appearing 
in other parts of this report. In some States the agricultural and mechanical coliege is merged in the State 
university, and in such cases the figures given in the statistical tables apply to the entire institution.] 
      
  FEDERAL ACTS FOR THE BENEFIT OF THE COLLEGES OF AGRICUL- 
TURE AND THE MECHANIC ARTS. 
The principal acts providing for the support of instruction in these 
institutions are three in number: 
(1) The act of July 2, 1862, granting public lands to the States, 
known as the “first Morrill Act,’ and the act of March 3, 1883, 
amending the previous act and providing for the investment of 
capital. 
(2) The act of August 30, 1890, making yearly appropriations to 
the States and Territories in aid of colleges of agriculture and the 
mechanic arts, known as the “second Morrill Act.” 
(3) The act of March 4, 1907, known as the “ Nelson amendment,” 
increasing the annual appropriation to $50,000 per year to each 
State and extending the conditions for the use of the funds. 
In addition to the three acts supporting instructional work there 
have been three acts granting Federal aid for experimentation and 
extension work: 
(1) The act of March 2, 1887, the “Hatch Act,” granting $15,000 
to each State for agricultural experiment stations. 
(2) The act of March 16, 1906, the “Adams Act,” increasing the 
annual payment for experiment stations to $30,000 for each State. 
(3) The act of May 8, 1914, the “Smith-Lever Act,” making an 
annual appropriation to each State for agricultural extension work. 
There are also a number of subsidiary acts and amendments, such 
as the acts authorizing the detail of Army officers to the colleges as 
instructors in military science and tactics, the act authorizing free 
postage on reports, etc. 
The benefits of the act of 1862, or of later acts in lieu of it, are 
received by every State, and 53 institutions are thereby aided—one 
in each of 43 States, and two each in Massachusetts, Mississippi, 
South Carolina, Virginia, and Kentucky. Massachusetts divides its 
fund between the Agricultural College and the Institute of Tech- 
nology; while Mississippi, South Carolina, Virginia, and Kentucky 
divide the funds between institutions for white and colored students. 
The amount of the appropriation under the acts of 1890 and 1907 
is now fixed at $50,000 for each of the 48 States and the two insular 
371 
     
   
   
                                 
   
-P-A-G-E-378
      
    
     
   
      
      
     
   
    
              3872 EDUCATION REPORT, 1917. 
possessions—Porto Rico and Hawaii. Sixty-eight institutions are 
aided. Seventeen States maintain special colleges for colored stu- 
dents, which receive part of this found.

PROPERTY, 1915-16. 
Table 7, page 390, shows the value of property in detail; Table 8, 
page 393, the value of additions during the year. There has been 
an increase of $7,718,841 in the valuation of all property held for the 
benefit of the land-grant colleges, while the total expenditure for 
building operations during the year was reported at $6,027,018. 
The following tables show the comparative totals for the last five years, 
and some of the principal gifts, buildings, and improvements of the 
year are listed below.

    AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL COLLEGES, 1915-16. 875 
MORRILL-NELSON FUND. 
Funds Appropriated Under Acts of Congress of Aug. 30, 1890, and Mar. 4, 1907. 
The total appropriation for the year ending June 30, 1916, from 
the United States Treasury in aid of colleges of agriculture and the 
mechanic arts under the provisions of the acts of Congress of August 
30, 1890, and March 4, 1907, was $2,500,000, each of the 48 States 
and the two insular possessions receiving $50,000. Table 10, on 
page 400, gives the details for the year 1915-16. In addition this 
table shows $1,283.45 received from bank interest on daily balances 
during the year in three States and added to the principal. The 
annual installment has been fixed at $50,000 to each State since the 
year 1911-12. The following tables give the amount expended 
under each schedule and the proportion each year. 
Morrill- Nelson funds. 
Acts of Aug. 30, 1890, and Mar. 4, 1907.

LAND-GRANT FUND OF 1862. 
Income from Funds Created by the Land-Grant Act of 1862. 
Under the act of Congress of July 2, 1862, 10,929,215 acres of public 
lands were allotted to the different States; of these, 1,149,867 acres 
remain unsold. From the sale of these lands permanent funds have 
been created amounting to $15,105,925, and yielding an income of 
$916,151 for the benefit of the colleges. Table 11, page 404, gives the 
details of income and expenditure for the year 1915-16. The figures 
below are the totals for the past two years. 
Land-grant fund of 1862. 
  Principal of fund. Income for y Expenditures for ye

-P-A-G-E-413
CHAPTER VI. 
PROFESSIONAL SCHOOLS IN 1915-16. 
The first table given below, showing the number of schools, pro- 
fessors, students, and property, is a brief statistical summary of 
professional schools in the United States for the school year 1915-16. 
The table following it shows similar statistics for seven years. Re- 
turns were received from nearly all of the professional schools known 
to this bureau. A few did not report the number of students and 
graduates, and for them the figures for the previous year are pre- 
sented. The totals, therefore, may be assumed to be practically 
correct. A number of important schools connected with univer- 
sities and colleges state that separate reports of the value of grounds 
and buildings, endowment, income, and the number of volumes in 
libraries could not be made for the reason that these are used in 
common by different departments. It should be borne in mind 
that the totals here given are aggregates for the schools which reported 
these items. 
LAW SCHOOLS. 
The number of schools of law reported to the Bureau of Educa- 
tion for the school year 1915-16 was 124. Of these, 102 were depart- 
ments of universities, and 22 were independent schools. In the 
number of students a gain of 1,070 is shown and in the number of 
graduates there was a loss of 104 from the graduates of the previous 
year. This decrease may be attributed to the lengthening of the 
course in a number of law schools. 
Of the 124 schools reporting, 11 evening schools report a course 
of four years, 93 schools a course of three years, 19 schools a course of 
two years, and 1 school a course of one year. 
MEDICAL SCHOOLS. 
The number of schools of medicine is less by one school than in 
the year 1914-15. The loss in the number of students is 415; the 
loss was 1,738 students in the previous year. The loss in the number 
of graduates in medicine is 309, as against 303 for the school year 
1914-15. 
Forty-three schools of medicine demand as a requisite to admission 
one year of attendance in a recognized college. In 43 other schools 
407 
 
-P-A-G-E-414
  408 EDUCATION REPORT, 1917, 
two years of college work is required; in 1 school three years’ work is 
required, and in 3 schools four years’ work is required. 
NURSE TRAINING SCHOOLS. 
A gain of 11 is noted in the schools for the training of professional 
nurses, and a gain of 1,570 in the number of pupils. The increase is 
due to the opening of new hospitals in various sections of the country. 
The widest possible variety of conditions for the training of nurses 
exist, and generalizations from the totals and summaries should be 
made with due caution. 
TABLE 1.—General summary of statistics of professional schools, 1915-16.

-P-A-G-E-451
  CHAPTER VII. 
PUBLIC AND PRIVATE NORMAL SCHOOLS, 1915-16. 
This chapter presents the statistics of 279 public and private normal 
schools reporting to this office for the year ended June, 1916. 
In the regular training courses for teachers in the 279 normal 
schools there were enrolled 111,672, as compared with 100,325 
reported in 1915, showing an increase of 11,347 students. Of the 
111,672 students reported there were 2,785 preparing to be kinder- 
garten teachers. In addition to the students in training courses for 
teachers in these public and private normal schools, 32,450 students 
were reported as pursuing such courses in 1,373 public high schools, 
and 6,006 in 280 private high schools and academies. In universities 
and colleges there were 48,018 students in professional courses in 
education. These items are set forth in the following table, which 
makes a comparative showing for the past three years: 
Students in teachers’ training courses reported for four years. 
  
1912-13 | 1913-14 1914-15, 1915-16

1 Statistics not called for. 
The number of normal graduates reported from the 279 public and 
private normal schools for 1916 was 24,534, or 22 per cent of the 
number of normal students in these institutions.

-P-A-G-E-485
  
CHAPTER VIII. 
SUMMER SCHOOLS IN 1916. 
A complete directory of the summer schools reporting sessions held 
in 1916 is included in the educational directory for 1916-17, published 
by the Bureau of Education (Bulletin No. 43, 1916). -The directory 
gives the name and location of each school, the name of the director 
or principal, and the probable date of the session of 1917. 
There were 734 summer schools reporting sessions in 1916, of which 
63 were regular sessions of universities, 62 of colleges, 94 of norma] 
schools, 34 of other institutions, while 481 were reported as inde- 
pendent schools. 
The number of students enrolled was 298,219, which was an 
increase of 56,408 over the number enrolled in 1915. This does not 
include the pupils enrolled in the summer practice or observation 
schools often held in connection with teacher training schools and 
which in 1916 numbered 21,295. 
The average length of session was 7.3 weeks instead of 7.1 weeks as 
in 1915. 
Only 36 schools held sessions of less than 4 weeks; 345 held sessions 
of 4 or 6 weeks; 152 of 7 or 8 weeks; 114 of 9 or 10 weeks; 57 of 11 or 
12 weeks. The remaining 30 schools were in session from 13 to 21 
weeks, Z : 
Summer schools for the past six sessions.

CHAPTER IX. 
PUBLIC AND PRIVATE HIGH SCHOOLS, 1915-16. 
For the year ending June, 1916, reports were received by the 
Bureau of Education from 12,003 public high schools, with an enroll- 
ment of 1,456,061 students. The number of public high schools 
reporting and the number of students enrolled continue to increase 
each year. 
The number of students enrolled in the fourth year of public and 
private high schools in 1916 was 233,827, or 14.57 per cent of the total 
enrollment. The graduates numbered 215,801, or 92.30 per cent of 
the number enrolled in the fourth year class. 
The number of four-year high schools steadily increases. Of 
12,003 public high schools reporting, 8,906 had four-year courses. 
There were enrolled in these schools 1,362,514 students, or 93.57 per 
cent of the total high-school enrollment. 
Based upon the returns from 3,544 public high schools, summarized 
in Table 14, the estimated per capita cost of the public high schools 
in 1916 was $59.86. The financial statements of only those schools 
in which high-school cost was clearly separated from elementary 
expenditure was included in this tabulation. The 3,544 public high 
schools represented in this table reported 466,879 students and an 
aggregate income of $27,946,589. By applying the above per capita 
cost of $59.86 to the total high-school enrollment, the estimated cost 
of public high schools was found to be $87,000,000. 
Public high schools with 4-year courses.

-P-A-G-E-518
  512 EDUCATION REPORT, 1917. 
DENOMINATIONAL AND NONSECTARIAN SCHOOLS. 
The number of private high schools and academies reporting in 
1916 fell slightly below that of the preceding year, but the number of 
students remained practically the same. Of the 2,203 schools 
reporting, 1,570 were under the control or influence of religious 
denominations and 633 were nonsectarian. The enrollment by 
States in each of the schools of 12 denominations having 1,000 or 
more high-school students is given in Table 23. The number of 
schools controlled by each of 26 denominations with the teaching 
force and enrollment is shown in the following synopsis: 
Denominational high schools and academies. 
  
   
       
               
    
          Religious denominations. Schools. |Instructors.| Students.

-P-A-G-E-557
  CHAPTER X. 
COMMERCIAL AND BUSINESS SCHOOLS, 1915-16. 
The Bureau of Education has the names of more than 1,400 private 
commercial and business schools. There are hundreds of other busi- 
ness schools which are departments of normal schools, private high 
schools, and other institutions. Only 912 of the private business 
schools responded to this bureau’s request for statistical information 
in 1916. This was 69 more than the number reporting the preceding 
year. 
There were 192,388 students in the 912 business schools reporting, 
an increase of 9,102 over the preceding year. In 746 private high 
schools there were 17,228 students in business courses, while 2,844 
public high schools had 243,185 students in such courses. 
Students in commercial courses, 1915 and 1916. 
  
  
  
      1915 1916 
Classes of institutions, | Students. Students. 
Schools. | Schools. 
Male. | Female.| ‘Total. Male. |Female.| Total. 
Private high school 762 | 9,360 | 8,346] 17,706] 746] 9,056| + 8,172 | 17,298 Public high schools 2, 863 | 92 226 | 1167379 | 208,605 | 2,844 | 105, 142 | 138,043 | 243/185 Commercial schools. . 843 | 94° 870 | 88416 | 183,286 | “912 | 90,134 | 937 254 | 192) 388, 
matte ek See 4, 468 |196, 456 | 213,141 | 400,507 | 4,502 | 213,332 | 239, 469 | 452, sor 
  
The number of students in business courses in public and private 
normal schools and higher institutions has not been reported for a 
number of years. These and the enrollment in the hundreds of 
business schools not reporting would increase the total to at least 
475,000. 
The following synopsis relates exclusively to the statistics of the 
912 commercial and business schools reporting to this bureau:

-P-A-G-E-558
552 EDUCATION REPORT, 1917. 
  To supply the information desired by many correspondents of the 
bureau, the principal of each private commercial or business school 
was asked to answer this question: ‘‘What system of shorthand do 
you teach?” Answers were received from 701 of the 912 business 
schools reporting. Of these, 480 reported one system only, while 
221 schools reported two or more systems. 
teaching each system in 1916 is shown in the following table: The number of schools 
Shorthand systems taught in private commercial and business schools, 1915-16.

-P-A-G-E-617
  CHAPTER XI. 
STATISTICS OF SCHOOLS FOR NEGROES. 
The statistics of negro schools of all grades are included in the 
general educational statistics in other chapters of this volume. The 
leading facts concerning negro schools are presented in this chapter 
for the convenience of those who desire to make a separate study of 
such schools. 
In 1916, 22 States and the District of Columbia reported 167 
public high schools for negroes, with 716 teachers and 14,461 high- 
school students. Public schools reporting 10 or more students of 
high-school grade are included in this tabulation. The following 
synopsis will show the growth of these schools since 1910: 
Comparative progress of public high schools for negroes. 
  
  
   
     1910 1911 1912 1913 | 1914 1915 1916 
Schools. 141 150 159 156 161 164 167 
Teachers . 473 513 597 566 638 670 716 
UOMO oan oe ete 8,251 9, 641 10, 877 10, 594 11,770 12,967 14,461 
  
Tables 2, 3, and 4 relate to secondary and higher schools for 
negroes, excluding public high schools. Private high schools and 
academies and public and private universities and colleges and 
normal schools are included in this list. 
: 611
-P-A-G-E-618
EDUCATION REPORT, 1917. 612

         CHAPTER XII. 
STATE INDUSTRIAL SCHOOLS. 
There were 121 State industrial schools reporting to this bureau 
in 1916. These schools employed 1,361 teachers and enrolled 61,828 
inmates—49,009 boys and 12,819 girls. The average enrollment 
for the year was 35,603, as reported by 114 of the 121 schools. The 
number committed during the year was 24,617, of whom 79 schools 
reported 2,856 who could neither read nor write. Of the 24,535 
inmates discharged during the year, 109 schools reported 22,114 
who could both read and write. 
Some of these schools are not, strictly speaking, State institutions, 
but are controlled by private corporations and associations. They 
receive children committed by public authority, however, and re- 
ceive public appropriations to care for these children. The following 
institutions are of this class:   
Delaware Industrial School for Girls, Wilmington, Del. 
Junior State School, Athens, Ga. 
Chicago Home for Girls, Chicago, Ill. 
House of the Good Shepherd, Chicago, Ill. 
Convent of the Good Shepherd, Sioux City, Iowa. 
St. Elizabeth’s Home for Colored Children, Baltimore, Md. 
St. James’s Home for Boys, Baltimore, Md. 
St. Mary’s Industrial School for Boys of the City of Baltimore, Baltimore, Md. 
Plummer Farm School, Salem, Mass. 
House of the.Good Shepherd, Detroit, Mich. 
Sisters of the Good Shepherd, Grand Rapids, Mich. 
Hudson County Catholic Protectory, Arlington, N. J. 
New York Juvenile Asylum, Chauncey, N. Y. 
House of the Good Shepherd, New York, N. Y. 
St. Vincent’s Industrial School, Utica, N. Y. 
Glen Mills Schools, Glen Mills, Pa. 
Wisconsin Home and Farm School, Dousman, Wis, 
Progress of State industrial schools since 1900. 
      
    
        
            
          
    
  Number of schools reporting. 115 121

-P-A-G-E-650

-P-A-G-E-651
        CHAPTER XIII. 
SCHOOLS FOR THE BLIND AND THE DEAF. 
Tables 1 to 6 present the statistics of school for the blind. This 
bureau has a record of 71 schools for the blind in the United States. 
Of these, 58 are controlled directly by the State or by corporations 
which receive pupils at the expense of the State, 10 are under the 
control of the city boards of education, and 3 are privately controlled.” 
Only 61 schools for the blind reported to this office in 1916. These 
schools employed 687 teachers and enrolled 5,155 pupils. Property 
valued at $14,659,506 was reported by 48 schools, while 51 schools 
reported an aggregate expenditure of $2,009,693, including $214,906 
expended for buildings and improvements. The per capita cost of 
maintenance and instruction was almost $380, or about $20 more 
than in 1915. 
Tables 7 to 15 present the statistics of 159 schools for the deaf. 
Of these schools 69 were State schools or received pupils at the 
expense of the State; 71 were public day schools controlled by city 
boards of education; and 19 were private schools. These schools 
employed 1,941 teachers and enrolled 14,733 pupils. Of the State 
schools 66 schools reported property valued at $21,041,425, and 65 
schools reported an aggregate expenditure of $3,850,476, of which 
$324,727 was expended for buildings and improvements. The per 
capita cost of instruction and maintenance in State schools for the 
deaf averaged $318, or nearly $20 a year more than in 1915. 
645

  CHAPTER XIV. 
SCHOOLS FOR THE FEEBLE-MINDED. 
There were 38 State schools and 28 private schools for the feeble- 
minded which reported to this bureau in 1916. Public day schools 
for subnormal children were reported in 118 cities. Detailed sta- 
tistics of these schools appear in Tables 6, 7, and 8. Special insti- 
tutions for nervous children may be found in Table 9. 
TasLe 1.—Summary of State and private schools for the feeble-minded, 1915-16: In= 
structors and inmates.

$254, 564] 13| $18,849] $196,613] $252, 462 
1 21,000, 22,000   
        
    
The year 1915-16 shana a rane. increase, 64 per cent, in the 
number of cities which provide special schools or classes for back 
ward and subnormal children. The State of Minnesota encourages 
the formation of such classes by appropriating for their support, 
allowing each year $100 per capita for children enrolled therein. 
State law in New Jersey classes for subnormal children are 
limited to 15 pupils each. 
In the following table financial items do not appear, as such 
classes form a part of the city school system and separate accounts 
are seldom kept.
-P-A-G-E-681
SCHOOLS FOR THE FEEBLE-MINDED.
